A basic body of knowledge encompassing metabolism, immunology, nutrition, physiology, anatomy, neoplasia, wound healing, pathology, shock and resuscitation, and intensive care  forms the foundation of the surgical specialty known as “general surgery.”

The goal of general surgery is to treat problems with the gastrointestinal tract, including the esophagus, stomach, small and large intestines, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, appendix, bile ducts, and frequently the thyroid gland. Along with performing endoscopic treatments like gastroscopy and colonoscopy, they also treat illnesses of the skin, breast, soft tissue, injuries, peripheral artery disease, and hernias.

Why choose Hope Hospitals for General surgery?

A skilled and committed team of consultants staff the Department of General  at Hope Hospital around-the-clock with the goal of giving patients access to cutting-edge surgical treatment options.Hope Hospital’s experienced general surgeons work alongside anesthesiologists, nurses, rehabilitation specialists, and physical and occupational therapists as part of a clinically integrated team.

Hope Hospital’s experienced general surgeons work alongside anesthesiologists, nurses, rehabilitation specialists, and physical and occupational therapists as part of a clinically integrated team

Our services in General surgery

    • Endocrine surgery – The adrenal glands located directly above each kidney in the belly and the thyroid and parathyroid glands in the neck can entirely or partially be removed by general surgeons.
    • Trauma surgery – Injuries to the head and neck, abdominal region, chest, legs, feet, arms, and hands can all be properly diagnosed and treated by trauma surgeons
    • Cardiothoracic surgery – is the medical specialty that focuses on the surgical treatment of organs located within the thoracic cavity. This includes the treatment of disorders that affect the  heart disease,  lung disease, and other pleural or mediastinal structures.
  • Vascular surgery – vascular surgery, also known as arteries, veins, and lymphatic circulation, is a specialization of general surgery that manages illnesses of the circulatory system by medicinal treatment, catheter-based techniques that are minimally invasive, and surgical reconstruction.
  • Breast surgery – The bulk of non-cosmetic breast surgeries, including breast cancer evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment, are carried out by general surgeons, from lumpectomies through mastectomy.
  • Colorectal surgery – General surgeons treat a wide range of major and minor colon and rectal disorders, including rectal and colon cancer, hemorrhoids gastrointestinal bleeding, and diverticulitis colon. Inflammatory bowel diseases, such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn’s disease, are also treated by general surgeons.
  • Surgical oncology – focuses on the surgical treatment of tumors, particularly malignant ones, and is the branch of surgery that oncology has adopted.
  • Transplant surgery – In charge of all aspects of preoperative, surgical, and postoperative care for patients undergoing abdominal organ transplants. The liver, kidney, pancreas, and, less frequently, small bowel are among the transplanted organs.
  • Laparoscopic surgery – is a procedure that is carried out in the belly or pelvis utilizing a camera and small incisions (about 0.5-1.5 cm). With a few tiny abdominal incisions, the laparoscope facilitates diagnostic or therapeutic procedures.Modern surgical methods include laparoscopic surgery, often known as minimally invasive surgery, bandage surgery, or keyhole surgery.

 

What is a general surgeon ?

An expert in disorders of the esophagus, small bowel, liver, gallbladder, colon, skin, breast and pancreas is known as a general surgeon. They have received training in the application of surgery as a kind of care.

 

What would make me go to a general surgeon?

For a variety of conditions affecting the esophagus, small bowel, colon, gallbladder, pancreas, skin, breast, or stomach, you might visit a general surgeon.

 

How come the procedure is required?

Surgery may be necessary for a variety of reasons, such as pain relief or pain prevention, problem diagnosis, or improved body function. Ask your doctor to provide a detailed explanation as to why he or she is recommending this procedure for you, and check that you fully comprehend how the treatment could potentially benefit your health.

 

What may I expect when I recover?

Talk with your doctor about what you can anticipate experiencing in the first few days, weeks, and months following surgery. It’s important to understand how long you’ll be in the hospital, what restrictions you’ll have, and whether you’ll need any particular supplies or equipment once you’re released. You’ll be able to handle the surgery and recuperate more swiftly if you know what to anticipate.

 

Which anesthetic will be used?

Your doctor should explain why a local, regional, or general anesthetic is advised for your treatment. Ask to meet with the anesthesiologist or nurse anesthetist before your surgery. Preoperative Management covers anesthesia.

 

What alternatives do I have to this procedure? Based on my present medical situation, are there any additional therapy options?

Medication or non-surgical treatments like lifestyle modifications may improve a problem as well as surgery. Your doctor should fully discuss the pros and cons of these treatments so you can decide if surgery is necessary. The doctor may recommend “watchful waiting” to track illness development and changes in your health. If your situation stabilizes, you may be able to postpone surgery. After “watchful waiting,” surgery may be the best option.
